<ActiveMessage:\C[1]■EV発生■>
\N<Rozaro>Miss Segi, may I have a moment?
\N<Segi>Yes, Mr. Rozaro. What can I do for you?

\N<Rozaro>...I've heard a bit of troublesome gossip. It's about your
opponent in the upcoming match.

\N<Rozaro>As we discussed before, normally the identities of the
combatants in the training matches aren't disclosed to avoid
unnecessary contact and confusion between opponents before a
match.

\N<Segi>Yes... I've heard the same. That's why I've been hiding my
identity as well...
\N<Rozaro>Hm? What do you mean?
\N<Segi>Oh, no... It's nothing. Please continue.

\N<Rozaro>...However, there are those who leak details of their
opponent only to their close associates. Your next opponent
is one such person... Hojiko from the general store.
\N<Segi>Mr. Hojiko has...

\N<Rozaro>No need to worry. No one knows that you are Hojiko's
opponent. Officially, you're just a mysterious female
warrior, or so they say.
\N<Segi>...

\N<Rozaro>I only guessed it because you had informed me beforehand
that you would be participating in the training matches as
Yuia's proxy. I suspected that the mysterious warrior might
be you.

\N<Rozaro>The real issue isn't there... The bigger problem is that
there's no way he would do anything to give you an
advantage.
\N<Segi>What do you mean...?

\N<Rozaro>He runs the general store that supplies goods to this town.
It's unlikely he'll sell you any useful items during the
match or the preparation period.

\N<Segi>Indeed... That makes sense. But it can't be helped...
Everyone would take the best course of action to win, no
matter who they are.

\N<Segi>Surely... If I were in his position, I would do the same.
That's why I can't blame Mr. Hojiko...

\N<Rozaro>...You're too kind. That's one of your virtues, but in
battle, it's nothing but a hindrance.

\N<Rozaro>However... it's a charm of yours that I wouldn't want to
lose. I'll help as much as I can.

\N<Rozaro>...For now, don't expect to receive any supplies from
Hojiko's store. That means we'll have to find whatever you
need for the fight inside the ruins.

\N<Segi>Understood. Thank you for your help. I'm really glad you're
here, Mr. Rozaro...
\N<Rozaro>...
A

\N<Rozaro>...For the time being, we can't expect to receive supplies
from Hojiko's store. That means we'll have to find the
necessary equipment for battle within the ruins.
A

\N<Man>If you don't need anything, please don't talk to me.
Drinking here is the only way I can forget this harsh
reality...

\N<Man>The residents have started fighting each other at the
training sessions, and everyone's becoming more
aggressive... Perhaps this is partly what those from Luda
are aiming for.

\N<Man>These days, even in a place like this, Luda's soldiers show
up. I just want to drink my booze in peace...

\N<Man>I don't have the strength to win matches, nor do I have the
power to train myself against monsters in the ruins. Is it
my fate to just die like this...

\N<Man>It's embarrassing to admit, but my wife and I have grown
cold towards each other, and we no longer function as a
married couple.

\N<Man>Yet, why must I risk my life for her sake by participating
in the training soldiers' tournament...

\N<Shopkeeper>Whether they're from Luda or not, a customer is a customer.
As long as I get paid, I'll provide the appropriate
hospitality.

\N<Shopkeeper>There's no point in being stubborn about it, after all, I've
got to make a living too.
<ActiveMessage:\C[10]■EV発生■>
\N<Segi>...

\N<Shopkeeper>What's the matter, standing there like that. If you've come
here, does that mean you've come to work?

\N<Shopkeeper>I was hoping you'd come. It might have been a series of
misfortunes for the missus, but I've made sure to provide a
fair compensation for it.
\N<Segi>I... did not intend to sell my heart just for the reward.

\N<Shopkeeper>I understand, you and our establishment are in the same
boat, so to speak. That's why I want to help you out.

\N<Shopkeeper>Well, that's how it is. Are you convinced? As usual, I've
prepared a change of clothes upstairs, so I'm counting on
you, okay?
\N<Segi>...

\N<Shopkeeper>What's the matter, standing there like that. If you've come
here, does that mean you've come to work?
\N<Segi>But...

\N<Shopkeeper>Ah, are you talking about last time? Well, in this line of
business, various things can happen over drinks.

\N<Shopkeeper>But still, you came here despite that. Isn't that your
answer? You yourself must need to earn a living here, right?
\N<Segi>That is...

\N<Shopkeeper>I said I wouldn't get involved in your personal
circumstances. Of course, serving here isn't something I'd
force on you.

\N<Shopkeeper>Well, that's how it is. Are you convinced? As usual, I've
prepared a change of clothes upstairs, so I'm counting on
you, okay?
\N<Segi>...
\N<Shopkeeper>Hey, glad you came, missus. I was hoping you'd come again.
\N<Segi>...

\N<Shopkeeper>Heh, you won't attract customers with such a gloomy face.
You've got to be brighter when you're in front of people,
right?

\N<Shopkeeper>Of course, I won't get involved in your personal affairs. I
have no intention of sticking my nose where it doesn't
belong. Our relationship is strictly business.

\N<Shopkeeper>Heh, feeling relieved? As usual, I've prepared a change of
clothes upstairs, so I'm counting on you, okay?
\N<Segi>Um...

\N<Shopkeeper>Glad you came again, missus. Just between us, I actually
thought you would come.
\N<Segi>...

\N<Shopkeeper>Ah, rest assured. I'm not interested in your personal

\N<Shopkeeper>The issue is that you can attract customers. And I can

\N<Segi>...

\N<Shopkeeper>Shall we move on to the job at hand? Though this time

need is your service as a hostess. Of course, the reward

\N<Segi>Wait, please. I haven't yet said that I would take the

\N<Shopkeeper>...Is that so?
\N<Segi>...Yes.
\N<Shopkeeper>Hahaha, let's forget about the troublesome stuff for now.

\N<Shopkeeper>Like I said before, I can compensate you for your work. And
in the way that you desire most... right?
\N<Segi>...

\N<Shopkeeper>Well, that's how it is. As usual, I've prepared a change of
clothes upstairs, so I'm counting on you, okay?
\N<Segi>Um...
\N<Shopkeeper>Hm? What is it, missus?

\N<Segi>That is... I saw the request board. If it's alright with
you, I thought maybe I could be of some help...

\N<Shopkeeper>The request board? Are you saying you'll take on a job from
it?
\N<Segi>Yes, if it's okay with you, I would like to help out.

\N<Shopkeeper>That would be a great help. If it's the missus doing it,
it's all I could ask for.
\N<Segi>...?
\N<Shopkeeper>Then, let me explain the details of the request right away.
\N<Segi>Yes, please do.

\N<Shopkeeper>Although it's a simple matter. What I want to ask of you is
some easy assistance with customer service.

\N<Segi>Assistance with customer service... Understood. So what
should I do...?

\N<Shopkeeper>Yeah, could you go upstairs for a bit? There are
preparations there.
\N<Segi>...?

\N<Shopkeeper>Well, I'll talk about the specifics later. So I'm counting

\N<Shopkeeper>Let's forget about all the troublesome stuff for now. Like I

\N<Segi>...

\N<Shopkeeper>There's no point in being stubborn about it, after all, I've

\N<Hojiko's Wife>Do you need something? If you think our marital spat is some
kind of spectacle, I won't stand for it, you know?
\N<Segi>W-Wait, please, I didn't mean anything like that...

\N<Hojiko's Wife>You're saying you weren't thinking that? Hmph, I wonder
about that. Nobody can really tell what's going on in
someone else's head. Of course, that includes me, my
husband... and you.

\N<Hojiko's Wife>It must have been quite the shock for you, having a husband
who's both good-looking and capable. You probably assumed
he'd take care of everything, didn't you?

\N<Hojiko's Wife>Ahh, how envious I am. If my husband had been someone like
Mr. Yuia, none of this would have happened...
A
